I thought it's going to be a quick adventure, but honestly, the game itself was far more complicated than I could imagine. Sometimes I even felt lost in what exactly I have to do in order to progress further, but that's exactly what made the game so interesting. If I had to describe it in few words, I am down to say it's literally a work of art. It uses the occult-horror setting of Project Kat and throws in a pinch of fantasy, and it seriously ups the horror with some really scary moments. The atmosphere is incredible - creepy without relying too much on jumpscares. Instead, it uses tension, unsettling visuals, and an eerie soundtrack to create a chilling mood that stays with you. The pixel art is simply beautiful. It's the kind of horror that makes you ask for even more!

The game is engaging, with multiple endings (so far, only one being a "good" ending, while the rest depict different ways to die), secrets to discover, and a deep world with lore. There are just so many things you can do to figure out various puzzles, and exploration is where this game shines. While you can fly through it in a couple of hours, taking your time to find everything makes it a much more rewarding experience (Especially for all the achievements hunters out there). The characters are a major plus point too - Lacie, Aoi, and Sai are just so cute, and even the NPCs (Spider, Kozmo, Rune,) have so much personality. I personally loved Miss Knives backstory. Itâ€™s honestly ridiculous that a game of this quality is completely free! The authors obviously put their heart and soul into this, and they ought to get all the support they can get. If this is only Chapter 1, I don't know how I'm going to manage to wait for whatever comes next.

The story only got interesting after mid-game and at the beginning of the ending. The prequel really got me interested in the beginning, but Chapter 1 really failed this time. Also, she isnâ€™t that much of an interesting character either. Design-wise, unlike the previous game, it felt like this is some kind of OC story project. Prequel heroine Kat didnâ€™t have much to her, but still managed to be more likeable with how she could interact and respond. The other character, Sei, is the same as well. Horror/chase segments need more polishing. Most of the time, you canâ€™t react since enemies literally instakill you unless you know what would happen beforehand. Overall, I finished this game with satisfaction. They managed to pull the game together in the mid-final stages. Iâ€™m really interested to see how the story goes. The art and atmosphere are extremely good, and the gameplay is not any worse. 

The puzzles are unique and, as advertised, have several substantially different solutions. If you can think of some strange way of solving a puzzle, then it will *probably* work in the game and let you progress without even noticing the several different ways you could have achieved the same result. 

Unlike many rpgmaker-esque puzzle games, there is little possibility of getting stuck without direction, the objectives which the game displays, combined with the very open approaches to puzzles allows you to progress very smoothly.

The game is also FILLED with missable details, interactions, and characters. There are loads of optional side activities and puzzles which you very well may not even realize you are progressing until you suddenly complete them by chance. These can often introduce entirely new characters, and even provide items which can give you unique solutions to future puzzles. Exploring thoroughly and figuring out uses for EVERYTHING in your inventory is very rewarding in this game.

Now, the main character, Lacie. I find her, very, VERY likeable. Her backstory and personality does a very good job at both setting up the stakes in the story and making your care about everything that happens to her. I found myself very much worrying for her safety and emotions throughout the game and genuinely feeling awful whenever she met any nasty ends (Of which there is no shortage of). She might be my highlight of the game by far, and, of course, her design is very cute. The other characters are quite entertaining as well, though they have had quite a bit less time to shine than Lacie.

And the story which Lacie finds herself in? While the chapter's story mostly revolves around Lacie and has very good intrigue built up throughout, it unbelievably shines at certain points, especially in the beautiful cutscenes with art. It would be spoiling to go on deeper, but trust me: the game is very, very good at making you care for characters and their backstories, all of which culminates in an incredible final sequence which could fit right in Touhou. 

Oh yeah, speaking of that, the game isn't just walking, plot, and puzzles. There are a few (light) chase sequences, some (lighter) stealth sections, and bullet minigames which are very, very fun. (And it even lets you skip them since they aren't a walk in the park!)

I love this game, and can't wait for chapter 2.

I'm assuming that's how this series is going to be as a whole. Just a bunch of random stories from different people that somewhat loosely take place in the same universe. Paper Lily Chapter one often felt confusing and there was a lot of times I found myself saying, "what even happened?" Most other solutions straight up just lead to death or some confusing unescapable faith like with the fairy circle, and yes, I know that there is a way out. I felt like Project Kat had set up a really good story and theme for what the series could be and unfortunately it kind of went to waste. I did still like the game. I like the artstyle, the characters, and the clear dedication put into this game but it just didn't hit as hard for me. But it's still worth checking out either way. I can see why people would love these things, it's just not for me.

Paper Lily - Chapter 1 is a magnificent indie horror RPG game.  Every aspect of the game is finely crafted.  The story is highly intriguing and is based upon Lacie's efforts to cure her unusual condition that is of apparently supernatural origin by performing a ritual that, hopefully, will ultimately lead to answers.  The writing is excellent and there are several interesting and memorable characters.     

There is an abundance of lore to be discovered through inspecting objects, exploration, talking to characters and completing tasks for them, and obtaining various endings.  One particularly impressive feature of Paper Lily is the game's extremely high level of interactivity and vast number of character reactions and scenes.  Additionally, there are a large number of possible dead end endings alongside the true ending, with the latter setting the stage for Chapter 2.    

This game also features numerous decisions and in some cases the player's choices are referenced later and/or affect for which specific items are available or not.  It also seems very likely that several of the player's actions or decisions made in Chapter 1 will carry over to future chapters.  

The phrase "There is always another way" appears frequently within the game and, indeed, it is very frequently that are multiple ways to go about completing or tasks or gaining access to new areas.  The gameplay contains a variety of puzzles and various events alongside exploration, item collection, stealth sections, and interacting with characters.  

The music and art are also top notch and fit the game perfectly.  The art style for the characters and the sprites are especially good. 

Paper Lily is a top tier game.  Everything about it is very good, including the narrative, characters, lore, writing in general, the numerous and often consequential decisions, fine gameplay, superb art, and excellent music.  I highly recommend this game.

Cons:
- Surprisingly heavy on the PC, temperatures sky-rocket with the game open. 
- A lot of pathways rely on VERY precise patterns of actions. This is fun for those who play it once-through and can feel that their actions have genuine consequences. However, I feel that a lot of interactions being locked behind previous "stage" progress doesn't feel as OBVIOUS. For example: the game will tell you to collect 3 items, 2 of them are readily available but the third can only be obtained had you kept an item from 2 hours ago, in a "yes or no" selection sequence. There are no indicators that due to your option being "incorrect" for this interaction, that you will never be able to pursue this pathway without a reload. This is just quite frustrating. It still leads you to the True Ending, if that's what you are aiming for, but it would be nice to not waste a good 10-30 minutes pathing around for an item which is unobtainable at that stage of the game. 
- Considering the depth of the story as you're playing, the True Ending is very lacklustre and makes it feel almost a waste of doing all of these puzzles and traversing through the game as you're not rewarded with absolutely anything. I assume that it was made this way to ensure that you play Chapter 2 to answer the ambiguity of the situation but it just feels more of a let-down than a cliffhanger. 
- Not a fan of how drawn-out some of the dead-ends are. To avoid spoilers, I will be vague, but there is a good section that is 15-20 minutes of looping around puzzles, dying constantly in ambiguous mazes only to come out that the entire sequence was your inevitable death and save reset anyway. 
- The keyboard controls aren't necessarily uncomfortable, but I'd have preferred being able to navigate the dialogue options etc. by clicking and moving my mouse rather than everything being done through arrow keys/WASD. 
- I wish that there were different death sequences other than just a red blood splatter on the screen that takes a few seconds to fade (especially considering just how many times you will die).

[h1]Paper Lily Review[/h1]
I am writing this review after getting all the achievements and endings.
[h2]Art, Music, Sound and Visual Effects[/h2]
The artstyle of the game is unique and beautiful. The game mainly features a pixel-art-style, which I love, the menus, dialogues, the dialogue character sprites and cutscenes are illustrated beautifully in non-pixel-art assets. The music is really nice throughout the game and the sound effects are on-point and immersive.
[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The game is perfect the first time you play it. Almost every object can be interacted with even if it can't be used and you can basically do anything you want without following the main story, which actually leads to different endings (there are plenty of them). I also like the fact that there are more than one solutions to most problems/riddles. The controls are okay for me and I think you can even change them if you like. The game also has many mini-games here and there which are enjoyable and not too challenging for casual gamers [spoiler]example: the spike mini-game at Red's treehouse[/spoiler] (If the mini-games are too hard for you, there is an option to skip them). The only problem is that after your first playthrough, if you are going for completion of all achievements, like I did, it gets fairly repetitive and even a bit boring. My suggestion to fix this is to add fast-travel and more convenient save-points.
[h2]Story[/h2]
The story is very good and fairly long for a [b]free[/b] game and I really enjoyed the way it unfolded.
Here is the story in short:
[spoiler]Lacie, a socially isolated girl burdened by a mysterious curse, receives a golden letter guiding her to perform a ritual. This leads her into a parallel world inhabited by demons and enigmatic entities. Seeking to lift her curse, she learns she must reach a lighthouse where someone named Red can help. Along her journey, she befriends Rune, a kindhearted demon, and encounters Sai, a peculiar human. Her path takes a dark turn when she stumbles upon a facility where demons conduct disturbing experiments. source:[url=https://paper-lily.fandom.com/wiki/Paper_Lily_Wiki]https://paper-lily.fandom.com/wiki/Paper_Lily_Wiki[/url][/spoiler]
[h2]Achievements[/h2]
Unlike the prologue (Project Kat), there are some achievements that are almost impossible to find without a guide and the not-so-convenient save-points make it very time consuming to try and find them on your own.
